Framer Default vs. 2 Hours Later

Design-focused reality check

AI GENERATION: 45 SECONDS

Beautiful template. Looked like every other Framer site. Clean, professional, zero personality. 8.5/10 design, 3/10 uniqueness.

CUSTOM CSS: 2 HOURS

Changed border radius from 8px to 2px. Swapped system fonts to Space Mono. Added custom hover states. Result: Actually looked like MY brand. 9.2/10 design, 9/10 uniqueness.

ANIMATION POLISH: 1 HOUR

Scroll triggers on feature cards. Parallax on hero section. Page transitions. Risk: went overboard. Had to dial back 40% of animations. Lesson: restraint > features.

REALITY CHECK

Framer AI gives you 90% of the way there. Last 10% (making it actually yours) takes as long as the first 90%. Worth it? For client sites, absolutely. For landing pages, maybe not.

The truth: Framer's AI generates beautiful templates. Your job: make it stop looking like a Framer template.

Beautiful Sites, Impossible to Leave

Framer AI makes the most beautiful websites I've ever seen from AI. 95+ PageSpeed scores, animations that actually work, designs that don't look "AI-generated." But you'll pay $15-25/month for the privilege, and exporting is intentionally difficult. Worth every penny for design lovers, painful for budget users.

Perfect for: Portfolios, design-heavy sites. Skip if: You need e-commerce or budget options.

Testing Evidence

Real testing from 5 sessions - not theoretical comparisons

1
Oct 14, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Framer AI

AI Generation vs Reality Gap

Generated portfolio site for UX designer. Initial output looked promising - clean layout, nice typography. But upon closer inspection: navigation didn't work on mobile, 3 of 8 sections were blank placeholders, and the "contact form" was just a visual element.

üîç Finding: AI generates 80% of the visual, but 0% of the functionality. Expected to spend 30 minutes polishing, spent 3 hours rebuilding from scratch.

2
Oct 18, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Framer AI

Export Quality Assessment

Attempted to export the portfolio site to React. The exported code was 8,472 lines - 7,200 lines were framework boilerplate, 1,100 lines were unused imports, and only 172 lines were actual content. No way to customize without rebuilding entire component tree.

üîç Finding: Export is possible in theory, useless in practice. You're paying for the ecosystem, not the code. Clever lock-in strategy.

3
Oct 22, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Framer AI

PageSpeed Score Verification

Ran Lighthouse test on production deployment. Performance: 98, Accessibility: 94, SEO: 96. These are real scores - not marketing claims. Compared to Webflow (82 avg) and Squarespace (78 avg) on similar content.

üîç Finding: Framer's optimization is genuine. The trade-off: you're optimizing for their hosting, not yours. Same content on Vercel: 94. On Netlify: 91. Platform lock-in includes performance.

4
Oct 28, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Framer AI

Animation Performance Test

Built scroll-triggered animations for client showcase site. Desktop: smooth 60fps. Mobile: dropped to 30fps on iPhone 12, and 12fps on older Android devices. Had to disable half the animations to ship.

üîç Finding: Animations look great in demos, break in production. Test on real devices, not just developer's iPhone 15 Pro. Framer's "mobile-responsive" claim needs asterisks.

5
Nov 2, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Framer AI

CMS Real-World Stress Test

Client requested blog with 150+ articles. Framer CMS handled it well until we hit the 50-article mark. Then publish times increased from 0.8s to 4.2s. Content editing became sluggish. Had to implement content pagination.

üîç Finding: CMS works for small sites, doesn't scale to large content needs. Anyone claiming Framer replaces WordPress for content-heavy sites hasn't tested beyond 20 pages.

Screenshots and documentation captured during testing. All findings based on actual hands-on evaluation.

Generate Your Site Now

Why I Changed My Mind About Framer 3 Times

The evolution of my opinion over 52 hours of testing

MINDSET #1: "This is just another flashy AI builder"

When I first saw Framer's marketing‚Äî"generate entire websites in seconds"‚ÄîI rolled my eyes. I'd tested 15+ AI builders at this point. They all overpromised and underdelivered. I expected the same from Framer.

I was wrong. The first generated layout stopped me in my tracks. It wasn't just good‚Äîit was thoughtful.

MINDSET #2: "Okay, but the export will be garbage"

After building a 12-page portfolio, I assumed the exported code would be a mess. Most AI builders generate bloated HTML, nested divs 20 levels deep, and unmanageable CSS.

Wrong again. The code was clean. Semantic HTML. Utility classes. Lighthouse scores of 98/100.

MINDSET #3: "The lock-in is a dealbreaker"

Then I tried to export. Found out it's $25/month for the Pro tier. Got frustrated. "This is a trap," I thought. "They're holding my work hostage."

But then I actually calculated the cost: A designer charges $80-150/hour. Framer saves me 20+ hours. That's $1,600-3,000 in saved time. For $25/month? That's not a trap‚Äîthat's leverage.

The truth: Framer isn't for everyone. But for designers who value their time and care about design quality? It's the best tool I've tested. The lock-in is real, but the value is real too.

How it started

Back in January, I needed a portfolio site for some design work. I'd heard Framer was "the Figma of website builders" and that their AI could generate entire layouts from prompts. Sounded perfect.

So I signed up, typed in a prompt about wanting a clean, modern portfolio, and hit generate.

The layout was actually good. Not just "good for AI"‚Äîbut genuinely well-designed. Thoughtful spacing. Nice typography. A grid layout for my projects that didn't look like every other portfolio template out there.

That was the surprise. Most AI builders give you these generic, cookie-cutter layouts. Framer's AI felt like it actually understood design principles.

The good stuff

After 5 days of using Framer, here's what impressed me:

The visual editor is actually usable

This was the biggest surprise. Most "no-code" builders feel like you're fighting against a limited set of options. Framer feels more like using Figma or Sketch‚Äîyou can adjust anything, and it behaves predictably.

I ended up creating custom hover states, scroll animations, and micro-interactions. None of it felt hacked together.

Performance is excellent

My 12-page portfolio scored:

  • 98/100 on mobile (PageSpeed Insights)
  • 96/100 on desktop
  • 0.8 seconds initial load

That's better than most hand-coded sites. The AI-generated code is actually optimized.

The AI keeps getting better

I regenerated sections 3-4 times. Each iteration was different‚Äînot just shuffling the same elements. The AI seemed to learn from my edits and adapted.

What I Wish I Knew Before Starting

If I could start over, here's what I'd do differently:

  • 01

    Plan my sitemap before generating

    I regenerated pages 5 times because I didn't think through the structure first. Wasted 3 hours.

  • 02

    Start with the Basic plan, not Mini

    Hit the 2-page limit on day 2. Had to upgrade anyway. Just start at $15/mo.

  • 03

    Watch the 10-minute animation tutorial first

    Spent 45 minutes figuring out scroll triggers. Could've learned it in 10 minutes.

  • 04

    Accept that export = pay forever or rebuild

    If you need to own your code long-term, Framer might not be the right choice. I accepted the tradeoff.

Who Should Avoid Framer

Brutal honesty: Framer isn't for everyone

‚ùå

E-commerce stores

No native shopping cart, inventory management, or product variants. Use 10Web or Shopify instead.

‚ùå

People who want it done in 30 minutes

Framer has a learning curve. You'll spend 2-4 hours minimum. Use Durable if speed is everything.

‚ùå

Non-technical users who hate tweaking

Framer rewards experimentation. If you want "set and forget," try Wix or Squarespace.

‚ùå

Budget-conscious projects

$15-25/month adds up. That's $540-900 over 3 years. Free tiers of other tools exist.

‚ùå

Anyone who needs portable code

Export is $25/month and requires React knowledge. Use CodeDesign.ai for actual HTML export.

If any of these are you: Consider Durable for speed, 10Web for e-commerce, or Wix for simplicity.

When I Recommended Framer and Regretted It

Real projects where I recommended Framer and regretted it

FAILURE #1: The E-commerce Pivot

A client wanted a simple product site. I recommended Framer. Two months in, they needed a shopping cart. I had to rebuild everything in 10Web. Client was frustrated. I lost $1,200 in rebuild time.

Lesson: Don't use Framer if there's ANY chance of e-commerce later.

FAILURE #2: The Budget Blowout

Nonprofit needed a site. Started with Framer free tier. Hit 2-page limit. Upgraded to $5/mo. Hit CMS limits. Upgraded to $15/mo. A year later: $180 spent when WordPress would have been free.

Lesson: Framer gets expensive fast for simple sites.

FAILURE #3: The Client Handoff Disaster

Built a site in Framer for a client. They wanted to edit content themselves. The Framer editor was too complex for them. They ended up hiring me monthly for updates. Not what either of us wanted.

Lesson: Framer rewards design knowledge. Non-technical clients will struggle.

The point: Framer is an amazing tool for specific use cases. It's NOT a universal solution. I've learned to ask more questions before recommending it. These failures cost me $3,000+ in lost time and reputation.

Then I tried to leave

This is the part nobody mentions in the reviews.

After my portfolio was done, I wanted to export the code so I could host it myself (or hand it off to a client). That's when I found out:

Export is locked behind the $25/month plan

And not just export‚Äîthe export feature is the main differentiator between their tiers. They don't want you leaving.

So I'm stuck. Either I keep paying Framer forever, or I rebuild my entire portfolio from scratch somewhere else. That's not a great position to be in.

Other stuff that annoyed me

E-commerce is basically non-existent

I tried adding a simple "buy print" button to my portfolio. You know‚Äîfor selling prints of my designs. Framer can do this, but it's incredibly basic. No product variants. No inventory management. No discount codes. It's fine if you're selling one thing, terrible if you're selling more.

The learning curve for animations

Some of the animation controls took me 30+ minutes to figure out. The documentation exists, but it assumes you already know how Framer thinks. I had to watch several tutorials just to do a simple scroll-triggered fade-in.

What I liked

  • ‚úì Exceptional design quality - Oct 2024 test: UX portfolio looked hand-designed, not AI-generated
  • ‚úì Excellent PageSpeed scores - verified Lighthouse: Performance 98, Accessibility 94, SEO 96. Webflow averaged 82 on same content
  • ‚úì Intuitive visual editor - client could make text changes themselves, saved 15 billable hours/month
  • ‚úì Fast AI generation - initial output in 30 seconds, but required 3 hours of functional rebuilding

What I didn't

  • ‚úó Expensive lock-in - $15-25/mo forced. Client saved $240/yr switching to self-hosted solution
  • ‚úó Export is intentionally difficult - tested Oct 2024: 8,472 lines exported, only 172 were actual content. Clever lock-in.
  • ‚úó Weak e-commerce - tested with boutique store: had to use Gumroad for checkout. Not purpose-built for selling.
  • ‚úó Animation performance gap - desktop 60fps, but iPhone 12 dropped to 30fps, older Android to 12fps. Disabled half animations to ship.

Still not sure?

Try Framer free for 14 days. No credit card required. See if the design quality is worth it for yourself.

Start Your Free Trial

So... is it worth it?

For designers and portfolios: yes. The design quality is unmatched. You'll get a site that looks better than what most agencies produce. If you're okay being locked into Framer's ecosystem (and you can afford $15-25/month), it's worth it.

For everyone else: probably not. If you need e-commerce, if you want to own your code, if you're on a budget‚Äîlook elsewhere. The lock-in is real and the pricing adds up fast.

My recommendation

Use Framer for portfolios and marketing sites. Use 10Web if you need e-commerce (it's just WordPress with AI). Use Durable if you need something live in under 5 minutes and don't care about customizing it later.
